StartingTimeOfDoses: Recommended for all pregnant women at any stage of pregnancy, particularly those who will be in the 2nd or 3rd trimester during the influenza season
WhenShouldYouGetIN: Recommended for all pregnant women at any stage of pregnancy, particularly those who will be in the 2nd or 3rd trimester during the influenza season
WhereGetIt: Administered based on healthcare provider's recommendation

SideEffects: Mild soreness or redness at the injection site
Precautions: Individuals with a history of severe allergic reactions to a previous dose should consult with a healthcare professional
AdditionalInformation.OtherNotes: Influenza vaccine helps protect against seasonal influenza viruses.

StartingTimeOfDoses: Recommended as a single dose between mid 2nd trimester and early 3rd trimester of each pregnancy (ideally at 20–32 weeks)
WhenShouldYouGetIN: Recommended between mid 2nd trimester and early 3rd trimester of each pregnancy (ideally at 20–32 weeks)
WhereGetIt: Administered based on healthcare provider's recommendation

SideEffects: Pain or swelling at the injection site
Precautions: Individuals with a history of severe allergic reactions to a previous dose should consult with a healthcare professional
AdditionalInformation.OtherNotes: dTpa vaccine provides protection against diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis during pregnancy.

StartingTimeOfDoses: Not routinely recommended as a dT only vaccine. Pregnant women can receive dT vaccine under certain circumstances, such as to manage a tetanus-prone wound, however depending on timing during pregnancy, a dTpa may be a preferred option (see Pertussis).
WhenShouldYouGetIN: Depends on circumstances, not routinely recommended
WhereGetIt: Administered based on healthcare provider's recommendation

SideEffects: Pain or swelling at the injection site
Precautions: Individuals with a history of severe allergic reactions to a previous dose should consult with a healthcare professional
AdditionalInformation.OtherNotes: dT vaccine provides protection against diphtheria and tetanus. Not routinely recommended as a standalone vaccine.

WhereGetIt: Administered based on healthcare provider's recommendation

Precautions: Individuals with a history of severe allergic reactions to a previous dose should consult with a healthcare professional
AdditionalInformation.OtherNotes: Cholera vaccine may be recommended in specific situations, such as travel to high-risk areas, but it is not routinely recommended.

WhereGetIt: Administered based on healthcare provider's recommendation

SideEffects: Mild redness or swelling at the injection site
Precautions: Individuals with a history of severe allergic reactions to a previous dose should consult with a healthcare professional
AdditionalInformation.OtherNotes: Hib vaccine may be recommended for pregnant women if they are at increased risk of Hib disease, such as women with asplenia, but it is not routinely recommended.

VaccineName: MenB (Meningococcal B) or MenACWY (Quadrivalent Meningococcal Conjugate)
WhereGetIt: Administered based on healthcare provider's recommendation

SideEffects: Pain or swelling at the injection site
Precautions: Individuals with a history of severe allergic reactions to a previous dose should consult with a healthcare professional
AdditionalInformation.OtherNotes: Meningococcal vaccines (MenB or MenACWY) may be recommended for pregnant women if they are at increased risk of the disease, but they are not routinely recommended.

VaccineName: PCV (Pneumococcal Conjugate Vaccine) - 13vPCV, 15vPCV [if ≥18 years of age] or 20vPCV [if ≥18 years of age]
WhereGetIt: Administered based on healthcare provider's recommendation

SideEffects: Pain or swelling at the injection site
Precautions: Individuals with a history of severe allergic reactions to a previous dose should consult with a healthcare professional
AdditionalInformation.OtherNotes: Pregnant women can receive a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (13vPCV, 15vPCV [if ≥18 years of age] or 20vPCV [if ≥18 years of age]) if they have a very high risk of invasive pneumococcal disease (IPD), such as those who do not have a spleen or evidence of reduced splenic function, or are immunocompromised, or have cerebrospinal fluid leak. However, it is not routinely recommended.

WhereGetIt: Administered based on healthcare provider's recommendation

SideEffects: Pain or swelling at the injection site
Precautions: Individuals with a history of severe allergic reactions to a previous dose should consult with a healthcare professional
AdditionalInformation.OtherNotes: Pregnant women can receive 23vPPV if they have a very high risk of invasive pneumococcal disease (IPD), such as those who do not have a spleen or evidence of reduced splenic function, are immunocompromised, or have cerebrospinal fluid leak. However, it is not routinely recommended.

WhereGetIt: Administered based on healthcare provider's recommendation

SideEffects: Pain or swelling at the injection site
Precautions: Individuals with a history of severe allergic reactions to a previous dose should consult with a healthcare professional
AdditionalInformation.OtherNotes: Q fever vaccine is not routinely recommended.

WhereGetIt: Administered based on healthcare provider's recommendation

SideEffects: Pain or swelling at the injection site
Precautions: Individuals with a history of severe allergic reactions to a previous dose should consult with a healthcare professional
AdditionalInformation.OtherNotes: Pregnant women can receive typhoid Vi polysaccharide vaccine if they are traveling to endemic countries where water quality and sanitation are poor. However, it is not routinely recommended.
